title: 'GPT-4 to be released this week' - Rockingrobots

last_post.content:
Welp here we fuckin go. GPT-4 is launched.

Back in the run-up to this release, four whole days ago, a bunch of people were talking over on the birdsite about their reactions to the pronouncements of those who'd gotten beta access, and MSFT's own discussions of what they believed it was going to be like.

Everybody in the gpt-4 trend was talking about how much faster it's reported to be, how many more things it can supposedly be applied to, all while blithely glossing over the fact that MSFT itself said that it is *Still Very Often Wrong* (https://www.rockingrobots.com/gpt-4-to-be-released-this-week/).

And that? That is the problem with our technoculture, in a nutshell.

And today, as seen in the image below, we have have these just… incredible scenes, live from OpenAI's GPT-4, where, when Chris Nicholson asked GPT-4 to give him a syllabus and mnemonics for learning Spanish pronunciation, not only did GPT-4 *Get Most Of The Pronunciations Wrong*, but— and I genuinely do not know which of these is worse— *the New York Times Reprinted The Exchange Without Calling This Out*.

I just… Holy shit y'all.

And then add to ALL of that the fact that MSFT just laid off their entire "Ethical A.I." team, in favour of their increasing the workload and making increasingly nebulous the remit of their "Office of Responsible A.I." And they did this right before this the GPT-4 release announcement went wide, specifically citing the pace of development as the reason they were laying their ethicists off (https://gizmodo.com/microsoft-ai-ethical-ai-bing-chatgpt-layoffs-1850223358).

Let me say that again:

Microsoft is laying off their whole "ethical A.I." team specifically BECAUSE they are increasing the range of integrations of their "A.I." tool throughout their *Widely-Used-By-The-U.S.-Government* product ecosystem.

…Which tells me they woefully misunderstand both "Ethics" and "A.I."

I mean this is damn near beyond parody at this point. If I were going to craft a list of shit to absolutely NOT DO in a time like this, it would look pretty much exactly like what OpenAI and MSFT are doing, right now.

Things are about to get real bad, real fast, and you can feel free to quote me on that.

title: Hackers Use Stolen Student Data Against Minneapolis Schools in Brazen New Threat

title: The first known visual acuity chart in Inuktitut, Cree, and Ojibwe

last_post.content:
#Indigenous #Canada #FirstNations #EyeCare #healthcare #EyeCharts #languages #alphabets

'The doctors developed the first known visual acuity charts in Canadian Aboriginal syllabics, an alphabet used in Inuktitut, Cree, and Ojibwe. From a sample of patients at the McGill University Health Centre who read Inuktitut and English, the doctors found that most patients received an equal or better score using the Inuktitut chart compared to the standard Latin alphabet chart.'

https://www.mcgill.ca/newsroom/channels/news/first-known-visual-acuity-chart-inuktitut-cree-and-ojibwe-346876

Sad news - Our former editorial board member Loet Leydesdorff passed away.

Loet was a passionate scholar, great colleague, and strong supporter of our journal.

He played a crucial role in connecting different science studies communities. To remember him, read our special issue 'Bridging the divide between qualitative and quantitative science studies', of which Loet was guest editor https://doi.org/10.1162/qss_e_00061.

Thank you Loet for everything you have done for our community.

title: On Star Trek: Discovery and Michelle Yeoh's accent

last_post.content:
I interviewed Michelle Yeoh a few years ago about #StarTrekDiscovery and I mentioned offhand that I'd written an article about what seeing her use her accent on the bridge of a starship meant to me.

She stopped and said "Wait, that was YOU?"

And then proceeded to talk about how much that article had meant to HER and how it contributed to the success of the show.

I can't think about it without crying.

(The original article: https://authory.com/SwapnaKrishna/On-Star-Trek-Discovery-and-Michelle-Yeohs-accent-aa6d2eb01b3a24970abf406c39146df33)

#MichelleYeoh #StarTrek #Oscars

title: Is Liberalism Worth Saving?, by Patrick J. DeneenFrancis FukuyamaDeirdre Nansen McCloskeyCornel West

last_post.content: “I was having a conversation just the other day with my mail carrier, and I said, Why are you delivering mail on Sunday? And she said, Because if we don’t do it, Amazon will start using UPS and stop using the post office. So, in order to keep working with Amazon, my postal carrier has to deliver mail every day of the week. We should really think abt what it would mean to have at least one day of rest for every person in our society.…” https://harpers.org/archive/2023/02/is-liberalism-worth-saving-francis-fukuyama-cornel-west-deirdre-mccloskey-patrick-deneen/

as usual, just start by reading Matt Levine when you have any questions about anything going on the financial markets. I don’t think the government action was a bailout, because the parties who typically are most rewarded by receiving a bailout are the ones who lost the most money: shareholders, bondholders, and executives. Depositors won out, which means that individuals being paid by the companies whose money was in the banks that failed will get paid. https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2023-03-14/svb-took-the-wrong-risks

title: Acts of Service, by Dizz Tate

last_post.content:
I love this memoir of waitressing, which played a huge part in my own becoming: “Running btw the kitchen + the floor felt like crossing btw two worlds, between the tension in the back where something was on fire, + the front, where I pretended everything was perfect. And sometimes it did feel that way, like a loud, noisy, messy version of perfection: a lot of people who liked each other talking at the same time.”

https://harpers.org/archive/2023/02/on-waitressing-acts-of-service/

- Add new More section with Classic, Local, and Federated Timeline, Your Posts, Bookmarks and Favourites
- The Post & Reply window can be inline now (there’s a Preference setting as well)
- When replying to a mention, the visibility is `direct` by default
- Added a Toolbar to contain the main UI actions
- Timeline names are sorted now
- Add mini profiles to notifications view
- Many bugfixes

title: Good Science Isn’t Enough - T. Callahan - Medium

last_post.content:
"I used to think the top environmental problems facing the world were global warming, environmental degradation, and ecosystem collapse, and that we scientists could fix those problems with enough science. But I was wrong. The real problem is not those three items, but greed, selfishness, and apathy. And for that, we need a spiritual and cultural transformation. And we scientists don't know how to do that.”
- Gus Speth, U.S. Natural Resources Defense Council

LEARN MORE HERE -- https://medium.com/@thelandoft/good-science-isnt-enough-be307e594729

title: The disabled villain: why sensitivity reading can’t kill off this ugly trope

last_post.content:
"If we replace older and ostensibly more stigmatising words with newer and softer-sounding labels, but do nothing to change the context in which the words appear, we leave the job half done. Arguably, we also risk new words and euphemisms being overtaken by old stigmas."

The headline and opening premise here are deliberately a little sensationalist, but overall it's a thoughtful piece on the (very) old trope of disfigured villains:

https://www.theguardian.com/news/2023/mar/14/the-disabled-villain-why-sensitivity-reading-cant-kill-off-this-ugly-trope

title: Microsoft was already using OpenAI’s GPT-4 model for the Bing AI chatbot

last_post.content:
Bing has been using GPT-4. I guess Microsoft was calling the model Prometheus to avoid admitting it was GPT-4.

https://www.theverge.com/2023/3/14/23639928/microsoft-bing-chatbot-ai-gpt-4-llm

This explains some of Bing's erratic behavior. GPT-4 would have completed training well before ChatGPT was put together, and thus would not have had all the RLHF advances. Microsoft must have also done some of it's own fine-tuning to teach it to respond to Sydney.

title: Docker is sunsetting Free Team organizations | Hacker News

last_post.content:
Say what you will about Heroku unceremoniously getting rid of their free tiers and screwing over significant parts of the open source ecosystem, at least they gave more warning than DockerHub.

If you're on the free tier at DockerHub, you have 30 days before services get shut off and 60 days before all your data is deleted:

https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=35153949
